title: Job Chapter 39 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 39 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 39 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 39.

questions.question: According to Job 39:1, what animal's birthing time does God ask Job if he knows?
options: Wild goats of the rock
Lions of the forest
Fish of the sea
Birds of the air
questions.correctAnswer: Wild goats of the rock
questions.explanation: Job 39:1 specifically asks if Job knows the time when the wild goats of the rock bring forth.

questions.question: What does Job 39:5 say about the wild ass?
options: Who hath sent out the wild ass free?
Who hath tamed the wild ass?
Who hath fed the wild ass grain?
Who hath made the wild ass wait?
questions.correctAnswer: Who hath sent out the wild ass free?
questions.explanation: Job 39:5 asks who has sent out the wild ass free, highlighting its freedom in the wilderness.

questions.question: According to Job 39:9, which creature is questioned about being willing to serve or abide by a crib?
options: Unicorn
Wild ass
Peacock
Hawk
questions.correctAnswer: Unicorn
questions.explanation: Job 39:9 asks if the unicorn will be willing to serve or abide by a crib, emphasizing its wild nature.

questions.question: What does the ostrich do with her eggs according to Job 39:14?
options: Leaves them in the earth and warms them in dust
Builds a nest in the tree
Hides them under leaves
Protects them in a cave
questions.correctAnswer: Leaves them in the earth and warms them in dust
questions.explanation: Job 39:14 states the ostrich leaves her eggs in the earth and warms them in dust.

questions.question: True or False: Job 39:7 says the wild ass respects the multitude of the city and the crying of the driver.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 39:7 says the wild ass scorneth the multitude of the city and neither regardeth the crying of the driver.

questions.question: What is the range of the mountains to the wild ass, according to Job 39:8?
options: His pasture
A dangerous place
A prison
A place of rest
questions.correctAnswer: His pasture
questions.explanation: Job 39:8 describes the range of the mountains as the wild ass's pasture.

questions.question: Who is described as not fearing the sword or turning back from it in Job 39:22?
options: The horse
The wild ass
The hawk
The unicorn
questions.correctAnswer: The horse
questions.explanation: Job 39:22 describes the horse as mocking fear, not being affrighted, and not turning back from the sword.

questions.question: According to Job 39:13, which two birds are mentioned to have wings and feathers?
options: Peacocks and ostriches
Hawks and eagles
Doves and sparrows
Crows and ravens
questions.correctAnswer: Peacocks and ostriches
questions.explanation: Job 39:13 mentions the goodly wings of peacocks and wings and feathers of the ostrich.

questions.question: Job 39:19 asks if Job has given strength to which animal?
options: Horse
Wild ass
Unicorn
Hawk
questions.correctAnswer: Horse
questions.explanation: Job 39:19 asks if Job has given strength to the horse and clothed his neck with thunder.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 39:27, the eagle makes her nest on high at Job's command.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 39:27 states the eagle mounts up at Job's command and makes her nest on high.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Job 39:26: 'Doth the hawk fly by thy ______, and stretch her wings toward the south?'
options: wisdom
strength
power
command
questions.correctAnswer: wisdom
questions.explanation: Job 39:26 asks if the hawk flies by thy wisdom and stretches her wings toward the south.

questions.question: What does Job 39:30 say the young ones of the eagle do?
options: Suck up blood
Fly with their mother
Rest on the rock
Hunt for prey
questions.correctAnswer: Suck up blood
questions.explanation: Job 39:30 says the young ones of the eagle suck up blood where the slain are.

questions.question: According to Job 39:4, what happens to the young of the wild goats after they grow up?
options: They go forth and return not unto them
They stay close to their mothers
They hide in the mountains
They follow the herds
questions.correctAnswer: They go forth and return not unto them
questions.explanation: Job 39:4 states the young grow up with corn, go forth, and return not unto their mothers.

questions.question: True or False: Job 39:16 says the ostrich is caring and fearful for her young ones.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 39:16 says the ostrich is hardened against her young ones, as though they were not hers, and her labour is in vain without fear.

questions.question: What is described as 'clothed with thunder' in Job 39:19?
options: The neck of the horse
The wings of the eagle
The horns of the wild ass
The feathers of the peacock
questions.correctAnswer: The neck of the horse
questions.explanation: Job 39:19 asks if Job has clothed the neck of the horse with thunder, describing its strength.

medium.title: Job Chapter 39 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 39 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to trust God’s timing in their life. Based on Job 39:1-4, what biblical truth would you share about God's control over life and growth?
options: God knows the exact time when wild goats give birth and the young grow strong.
People can predict the birth and growth of wild animals by their own wisdom.
The wild goats and hinds care for themselves without God’s guidance.
It is unnecessary to trust God’s timing in natural processes.
questions.correctAnswer: God knows the exact time when wild goats give birth and the young grow strong.
questions.explanation: Job 39:1-4 highlights God's sovereignty over the natural processes of life and growth, showing that He controls the birth and development of wild animals, teaching us to trust His timing in all things.

questions.question: How does Job 39:5-8 teach us about contentment and trusting God’s provision in difficult circumstances?
options: The wild ass is given freedom and dwells in the barren wilderness, trusting God for provision.
The wild ass struggles because God does not care for it.
It is better to live in the city than in the wilderness.
God expects all creatures to live under human control.
questions.correctAnswer: The wild ass is given freedom and dwells in the barren wilderness, trusting God for provision.
questions.explanation: Verses 5-8 show that God provides for the wild ass even in harsh, barren lands, teaching us to be content and trust God’s care even in difficult or lonely seasons.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by their work responsibilities. Based on Job 39:9-12, what lesson about humility and trust in God can you share?
options: No creature, including the unicorn, willingly serves man without God’s authority.
The unicorn is obedient and will always do human work.
Strength alone guarantees success in work.
Humans should leave all work to animals.
questions.correctAnswer: No creature, including the unicorn, willingly serves man without God’s authority.
questions.explanation: Job 39:9-12 illustrates that even powerful animals like the unicorn do not serve humans unless God allows it, reminding us to humbly trust God’s authority and not rely solely on our own strength or efforts.

questions.question: How does Job 39:13-18 teach us about wisdom and understanding in parenting and family life?
options: Some creatures, like the ostrich, lack maternal wisdom and do not protect their young, showing the need for wisdom in parenting.
All animals care perfectly for their offspring by instinct.
Wisdom in parenting is unnecessary because children are self-sufficient.
Parental care is not important in family life.
questions.correctAnswer: Some creatures, like the ostrich, lack maternal wisdom and do not protect their young, showing the need for wisdom in parenting.
questions.explanation: Job 39:13-18 contrasts the ostrich’s lack of wisdom with God’s gift of understanding to humans, emphasizing the importance of wisdom and care in parenting and family life.

questions.question: How can Job 39:19-25 help believers develop perseverance and courage in facing trials?
options: The horse shows strength and fearlessness in battle, trusting in God’s power rather than fear.
The horse is fearful and weak when facing danger.
Believers should avoid all trials to stay safe.
Courage comes from human strength alone.
questions.correctAnswer: The horse shows strength and fearlessness in battle, trusting in God’s power rather than fear.
questions.explanation: Verses 19-25 depict the horse’s courage and strength in battle, which encourages believers to persevere and face trials boldly, trusting in God’s sustaining power rather than their own.

questions.question: A believer struggles with trusting God’s wisdom in decision-making. What does Job 39:26-30 teach about God’s sovereign control over nature and how should that impact our trust?
options: The hawk and eagle fly and nest by God’s command, showing His sovereign wisdom over all things.
Birds act independently without God’s involvement.
Wisdom is only human knowledge without divine guidance.
Trusting God is unnecessary in daily decisions.
questions.correctAnswer: The hawk and eagle fly and nest by God’s command, showing His sovereign wisdom over all things.
questions.explanation: Job 39:26-30 illustrates God’s control over even the flight and nesting of powerful birds, reminding us to trust His wisdom and sovereignty in our own decision-making.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 39:7, the wild ass respects the noise and commands of the city driver.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 39:7 states that the wild ass scorns the multitude of the city and does not regard the crying of the driver, indicating independence and freedom given by God.

questions.question: True or False: Job 39 teaches that God imparts wisdom to all creatures equally, including the ostrich.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 39:16-17 explains that God has deprived the ostrich of wisdom and understanding, showing that divine wisdom is a gift not given equally to all creatures.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Job 39:21 says the horse "paweth in the valley, and rejoiceth in his _______."
options: strength
speed
fear
weakness
questions.correctAnswer: strength
questions.explanation: Job 39:21 describes the horse rejoicing in his strength, symbolizing courage and confidence given by God in facing challenges.

questions.question: How does Job 39:1-4 encourage believers in the virtue of patience during trials?
options: God’s timing in natural processes like birth teaches us to be patient and trust His perfect schedule.
We should try to control all outcomes ourselves.
Impatience is rewarded by quick results.
Trials indicate God’s absence.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s timing in natural processes like birth teaches us to be patient and trust His perfect schedule.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-4 emphasize God’s precise control over birth and growth, encouraging believers to be patient and trust His timing in their own trials.

questions.question: What does Job 39:19-25 teach about the work ethic and integrity in facing challenges?
options: The horse willingly goes to meet armed men without fear, showing strength and faithful effort in duty.
The horse avoids all difficult work to stay safe.
Integrity is irrelevant in tough situations.
Work should only be done when easy.
questions.correctAnswer: The horse willingly goes to meet armed men without fear, showing strength and faithful effort in duty.
questions.explanation: These verses portray the horse as strong and fearless in battle, modeling a diligent and courageous work ethic in the face of adversity.

questions.question: A believer is feeling fear about their future. Based on Job 39:24-25, what encouragement can you give about God’s presence in conflict?
options: The horse is unafraid of the trumpet or battle because of its strength, teaching us to trust God in conflicts.
Fear shows lack of faith and should be ignored.
God abandons us in battle and trials.
Conflict is always to be avoided.
questions.correctAnswer: The horse is unafraid of the trumpet or battle because of its strength, teaching us to trust God in conflicts.
questions.explanation: Verses 24-25 show the horse’s fearless attitude toward war noises, encouraging believers to trust in God’s strength when facing fears and challenges.

questions.question: Based on Job 39:26-30, what biblical principle about spiritual discipline and attentiveness can be drawn from the eagle’s behavior?
options: The eagle watches for prey from a high place, teaching us to be watchful and focused in our spiritual lives.
The eagle acts randomly without purpose.
Spiritual discipline is unnecessary for believers.
Focus on immediate gratification rather than long-term vigilance.
questions.correctAnswer: The eagle watches for prey from a high place, teaching us to be watchful and focused in our spiritual lives.
questions.explanation: The eagle’s vigilance and strategic nesting in Job 39:26-30 illustrate the importance of spiritual alertness and discipline in the believer’s journey.

questions.question: How does Job 39:13-15 teach about the importance of wisdom in stewardship and responsibility?
options: The ostrich leaves her eggs vulnerable and forgets dangers, showing the consequences of lacking wisdom in stewardship.
All creatures wisely protect their possessions.
Stewardship is not important in life.
Responsibility can be ignored without consequence.
questions.correctAnswer: The ostrich leaves her eggs vulnerable and forgets dangers, showing the consequences of lacking wisdom in stewardship.
questions.explanation: These verses describe the ostrich’s careless behavior toward her eggs, highlighting the need for wisdom and responsible care in all areas of life.

questions.question: What does Job 39:6 teach us about contentment and trusting God’s provision in loneliness or hardship?
options: God has made the wilderness the home of the wild ass, teaching that provision and purpose exist even in barren places.
The wilderness is a place of abandonment with no provision.
Loneliness is always a sign of God’s displeasure.
We must avoid hardship at all costs.
questions.correctAnswer: God has made the wilderness the home of the wild ass, teaching that provision and purpose exist even in barren places.
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows God’s care in providing a dwelling for the wild ass in the wilderness, encouraging believers to trust God’s provision even in difficult or isolated circumstances.

hard.title: Job Chapter 39 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 39.

questions.question: In Job 39:1-4, the wild goats and hinds are described in terms of their birthing process. What literary device does this passage primarily use to emphasize God's control over nature?
options: Metaphor
Chiasm
Parallelism
Hyperbole
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Verses 1-4 use parallelism by repeating similar structures when asking about the timing of birthing and describing the young growing up, highlighting God's sovereign knowledge over natural processes.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'unicorn' in Job 39:9-12 in the context of ancient Near Eastern symbolism and Biblical typology?
options: It symbolizes untamable strength and freedom
It represents a mythical creature from Babylonian myths
It is a direct reference to a domesticated ox
It signifies the Messiah's humility
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes untamable strength and freedom
questions.explanation: The 'unicorn' here likely refers to a wild, powerful animal symbolizing strength that cannot be domesticated, emphasizing God's creation beyond human control (Job 39:9-12).

questions.question: According to Job 39:13-17, the ostrich is described as lacking wisdom. What does this imply about God's distribution of wisdom in creation?
options: Wisdom is selectively given according to divine purpose
All creatures naturally possess equal wisdom
The ostrich is a symbol of human folly
Wisdom is irrelevant in the animal kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom is selectively given according to divine purpose
questions.explanation: The ostrich's lack of wisdom (Job 39:17) highlights that God intentionally withholds understanding from some creatures, illustrating divine sovereignty over attributes granted in creation.

questions.question: In Job 39:19-25, the horse is described with vivid imagery such as 'clothed his neck with thunder.' What literary device is used here and what is its effect?
options: Personification, to depict the horse as a warrior
Simile, to compare the horse to thunder
Alliteration, to emphasize the horse's speed
Irony, to show the horse's vulnerability
questions.correctAnswer: Personification, to depict the horse as a warrior
questions.explanation: The horse is personified with warrior-like qualities, emphasizing strength and bravery in battle, reflecting the cultural importance of horses in ancient warfare (Job 39:19-25).

questions.question: What does Job 39:26-30 reveal about the eagle’s behavior, and how does this relate to the theme of divine providence?
options: The eagle acts independently, showing God’s control over all creatures
The eagle symbolizes human pride and ambition
The eagle’s flight is accidental, indicating chaos
The eagle’s nesting habits represent human settlements
questions.correctAnswer: The eagle acts independently, showing God’s control over all creatures
questions.explanation: The eagle’s purposeful flight and nesting reflect God’s providence and design over even the most majestic creatures, highlighting divine governance (Job 39:26-30).

questions.question: Which Hebrew word concept in Job 39:17 underscores the ostrich’s lack of wisdom, and what is its broader theological significance?
options: ‘Chokmah’ meaning wisdom, showing selective divine endowment
‘Ruach’ meaning spirit, indicating absence of life
‘Elohim’ meaning God, highlighting divine authority
‘Shema’ meaning hearing, emphasizing obedience
questions.correctAnswer: ‘Chokmah’ meaning wisdom, showing selective divine endowment
questions.explanation: The Hebrew term 'chokmah' denotes wisdom, and its absence in the ostrich (Job 39:17) illustrates God's selective granting of wisdom, reinforcing divine sovereignty.

questions.question: True or False: Job 39 describes the wild ass as a creature that seeks the company of city dwellers and obeys human commands.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 39:5-8 depicts the wild ass as free, dwelling in the wilderness, scorning cities and human drivers, emphasizing its independence from human control.

questions.question: How does the portrayal of the horse in Job 39 compare to its depiction in Psalm 20:7 and what thematic connection does this suggest?
options: Both emphasize the horse’s strength but highlight trust should be in God, not horses
Both depict horses as symbols of peace and prosperity
Job portrays the horse negatively while Psalm 20 praises it
There is no connection; the horse is absent in Psalm 20
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize the horse’s strength but highlight trust should be in God, not horses
questions.explanation: Job 39’s vivid horse imagery parallels Psalm 20:7’s warning against trusting in horses over God, reinforcing a biblical theme of divine sovereignty over human power.

questions.question: Which cultural or historical context helps explain the significance of the horse’s characteristics in Job 39:19-25?
options: Ancient Near Eastern warfare where horses symbolized military power
Agricultural societies that used horses primarily for farming
Nomadic tribes valuing horses for trade
Ancient religious rituals involving horse sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: Ancient Near Eastern warfare where horses symbolized military power
questions.explanation: The horse’s strength and fearless nature correspond to its role in ancient Near Eastern armies, underscoring the historical importance of horses in battle (Job 39:19-25).

questions.question: What is the significance of the ostrich leaving its eggs 'in the earth' and 'warmeth them in dust' as described in Job 39:14-15?
options: It highlights the ostrich’s apparent neglect contrasted with God’s providence
It shows the bird’s careful and wise parenting
It indicates a unique nesting practice for protection
It symbolizes resurrection and new life
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights the ostrich’s apparent neglect contrasted with God’s providence
questions.explanation: The ostrich’s neglectful behavior contrasts with God’s ongoing care, illustrating divine sovereignty despite creaturely flaws (Job 39:14-15).

questions.question: Job 39:1-4 and 39:26-30 both deal with animals and their natural behaviors. How do these passages contribute to the overall theological theme of the chapter?
options: They emphasize God's intimate knowledge and control over creation
They suggest animals possess human-like wisdom and reasoning
They imply unpredictability in natural order
They represent allegories for human kingdoms
questions.correctAnswer: They emphasize God's intimate knowledge and control over creation
questions.explanation: Both passages highlight God’s detailed governance over animal life, reinforcing the theme of divine omniscience and power in creation (Job 39:1-4, 26-30).

questions.question: Which poetic structure is evident in Job 39:19-25 that enhances the depiction of the horse?
options: Anaphora through repeated 'He' clauses
Chiasm emphasizing the horse's battle readiness
Acrostic spelling 'HORSE'
Parallelism contrasting fear and bravery
questions.correctAnswer: Anaphora through repeated 'He' clauses
questions.explanation: The repetition of 'He' at the beginning of verses or clauses (anaphora) intensifies the portrayal of the horse’s vigor and fearlessness (Job 39:19-25).

questions.question: Job 39:26 mentions the hawk flying 'by thy wisdom.' What is the significance of this phrase in relation to ancient wisdom literature?
options: It shows that natural phenomena operate under God's wise design
It implies the hawk has human-like wisdom
It suggests wisdom is a physical location
It represents a challenge to human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that natural phenomena operate under God's wise design
questions.explanation: The phrase indicates that even the hawk’s flight is ordered by divine wisdom, consistent with ancient wisdom literature emphasizing God’s control over nature (Job 39:26).

questions.question: How does the depiction of the wild ass in Job 39:5-8 serve as a contrast to domesticated animals in biblical and ancient Near Eastern contexts?
options: It symbolizes freedom and independence from human authority
It shows the wild ass’s usefulness in agriculture
It represents a divine punishment
It is praised for its obedience
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes freedom and independence from human authority
questions.explanation: The wild ass is portrayed as living in barren lands, ignoring human commands, emphasizing a theme of untamed creation beyond human control (Job 39:5-8).

questions.question: True or False: Job 39 suggests that humans have the ability to command eagles to build nests and fly in certain directions.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 26-27 emphasize that the eagle’s flight and nesting are not commanded by humans but by God’s design, illustrating divine sovereignty over nature.

theological.title: Job Chapter 39 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 39 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does Job 39 reveal about God's sovereignty over wild animals such as the wild goats and hinds?
options: God knows the exact time they give birth and oversees their life cycles
They reproduce without any divine oversight
Humans have control over their reproductive timing
Their birth is accidental and unmanaged
questions.correctAnswer: God knows the exact time they give birth and oversees their life cycles
questions.explanation: Job 39:1-2 emphasizes God's sovereign knowledge of the reproductive timing of wild goats and hinds, showing His providential care. This aligns with Psalm 104:21-22, Matthew 10:29, and Isaiah 40:12, demonstrating God's comprehensive governance over creation.

questions.question: According to Job 39, how does God demonstrate His wisdom in the behavior of the ostrich?
options: God has deprived the ostrich of wisdom and understanding
The ostrich is the wisest bird in creation
The ostrich carefully protects its eggs with great understanding
The ostrich builds nests in trees
questions.correctAnswer: God has deprived the ostrich of wisdom and understanding
questions.explanation: Job 39:15-17 explains that the ostrich leaves its eggs in the dust and is hardened against her young, illustrating a lack of wisdom given by God. This highlights God's sovereign control over creatures with varied instincts, as shown also in Proverbs 1:7 and Romans 11:33.

questions.question: What theological truth does the description of the horse in Job 39 teach about God's power?
options: God gives the horse strength and fearlessness for battle
The horse is weak and fearful by nature
The horse is independent from God’s control
The horse serves only humans without any divine influence
questions.correctAnswer: God gives the horse strength and fearlessness for battle
questions.explanation: Verses 19-25 depict God as the one who empowers the horse with strength and courage in battle, demonstrating divine sovereignty over natural and martial powers, consistent with Psalm 147:10-11 and Isaiah 31:1.

questions.question: What does Job 39 say about the wild ass and its dwelling?
options: God made the wilderness its home and the barren land its dwelling
It lives only in cultivated fields
It is domesticated and bound by man
It refuses to live in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: God made the wilderness its home and the barren land its dwelling
questions.explanation: Job 39:5-6 states that God sent the wild ass free and gave it the wilderness as its home, illustrating God's sovereign design in placing creatures in their natural habitats, reflecting Psalm 104:10-12 and Jeremiah 14:6.

questions.question: How does Job 39 describe the unicorn's willingness to serve man?
options: The unicorn will not be willing to serve or abide by man’s crib
The unicorn is obedient and domesticated
The unicorn serves willingly in the fields
The unicorn is mentioned as a mythical helper
questions.correctAnswer: The unicorn will not be willing to serve or abide by man’s crib
questions.explanation: Job 39:9-10 indicates the unicorn’s wild nature, refusing to be bound or serve man, symbolizing creatures beyond human control, emphasizing God's sovereignty, consistent with Psalm 29:10 and Job 41:1.

questions.question: What does the description of the eagle in Job 39 teach about God's providence?
options: The eagle mounts up at God's command and nests on high places
The eagle nests in low valleys by its own will
The eagle is independent of God’s will
The eagle cannot see its prey from afar
questions.correctAnswer: The eagle mounts up at God's command and nests on high places
questions.explanation: Job 39:27-30 reveals that the eagle’s flight and nesting are under divine control, illustrating God's providential governance over nature, paralleling Psalm 103:5 and Isaiah 40:31.

questions.question: What characteristic of the wild ass in Job 39 reflects the theme of freedom under God’s sovereignty?
options: It scorns the multitude of the city and ignores the driver’s voice
It is easily tamed and obeys humans
It lives in cities and farms
It is afraid of the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: It scorns the multitude of the city and ignores the driver’s voice
questions.explanation: Job 39:7 describes the wild ass as free and indifferent to human commands, highlighting God’s design for creatures to live according to their nature, reflecting Psalm 104:24 and Jeremiah 2:24.

questions.question: What does Job 39 imply about human ability to control the forces of nature?
options: Humans cannot bind or control wild creatures like the unicorn
Humans fully control all animals
Humans can domesticate every wild animal
Humans have no interaction with animals
questions.correctAnswer: Humans cannot bind or control wild creatures like the unicorn
questions.explanation: Verses 9-12 emphasize that certain animals resist human control, underscoring God's ultimate authority over creation beyond human dominion, consistent with Psalm 50:10-12 and Job 41:10-11.

questions.question: How does Job 39 illustrate God’s wisdom in the variety of animal behavior?
options: God imparts wisdom differently, as seen in the ostrich’s lack of understanding versus the horse’s strength
All animals have equal wisdom
Animals behave randomly without divine purpose
Animals are all foolish and equally ignorant
questions.correctAnswer: God imparts wisdom differently, as seen in the ostrich’s lack of understanding versus the horse’s strength
questions.explanation: The contrast between the ostrich (39:15-17) and the horse (39:19-25) reveals God's sovereign distribution of wisdom and strength, affirming His purposeful design, paralleling Proverbs 3:19 and Romans 11:33.

questions.question: What does Job 39 say about the peacock’s wings compared to the ostrich’s?
options: God gave goodly wings to the peacock and wings and feathers to the ostrich
The peacock has no wings
The ostrich has more colorful wings than the peacock
Both have identical wings
questions.correctAnswer: God gave goodly wings to the peacock and wings and feathers to the ostrich
questions.explanation: Job 39:13 notes God’s creative variety in wing design, reflecting His wisdom in creation, consistent with Psalm 104:12 and Matthew 6:26.

questions.question: According to Job 39, what is the attitude of the horse towards battle?
options: The horse rejoices in strength and is unafraid of the sword
The horse is fearful and avoids battle
The horse is indifferent to war
The horse refuses to go to battle
questions.correctAnswer: The horse rejoices in strength and is unafraid of the sword
questions.explanation: Verses 21-23 describe the horse’s confidence and joy in battle, signifying God's empowering presence, consistent with Psalm 20:7 and Isaiah 31:4.

questions.question: What does the passage in Job 39 communicate about God’s control over natural instincts in animals?
options: God controls instincts, such as the ostrich forgetting her eggs and the eagle seeking prey
Animals act independently of God
Instincts are random and purposeless
Animals learn instincts from humans
questions.correctAnswer: God controls instincts, such as the ostrich forgetting her eggs and the eagle seeking prey
questions.explanation: Job 39:14-17 and 28-30 show God’s sovereign control over animal behavior, reflecting His providence, as echoed in Psalm 147:9 and Jeremiah 10:13.

questions.question: What does Job 39 reveal about the relationship between strength and trust in animals like the horse?
options: Despite the horse’s great strength, humans cannot fully trust it to bring home the seed
The horse is completely trustworthy in all tasks
The horse is weak and unreliable
Humans have no need to trust animals
questions.correctAnswer: Despite the horse’s great strength, humans cannot fully trust it to bring home the seed
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 highlight that although the horse is strong, humans cannot rely on it for agricultural tasks, emphasizing God’s ultimate control, consistent with Psalm 20:7 and Jeremiah 17:7.

questions.question: What does Job 39 teach about God’s provision for creatures in their natural habitats?
options: God provides the mountains as pasture for the wild ass
Animals must find food without God’s provision
Animals create their own habitats
Humans provide all food for wild animals
questions.correctAnswer: God provides the mountains as pasture for the wild ass
questions.explanation: Job 39:8 states that the mountains are pasture for the wild ass, illustrating God’s provision and care for all creatures, consistent with Psalm 104:14 and Matthew 6:26.

questions.question: How does Job 39 describe the attitude of the horse towards the sound of the trumpet and battle?
options: The horse disregards the trumpet and smells battle from afar with excitement
The horse is terrified by the trumpet
The horse ignores battle noises completely
The horse runs away from battle
questions.correctAnswer: The horse disregards the trumpet and smells battle from afar with excitement
questions.explanation: Verses 24-25 show the horse swallowing the ground fiercely and laughing at the trumpet's sound, illustrating God’s gifting of courage, consistent with Psalm 45:5 and Isaiah 31:4.
